articles.headline: New Rules Restrict Bank Sales
articles.snippet: The board of the F.D.I.C. moved to relax some proposed rules while still imposing tough standards on private equity firms seeking to buy troubled financial institutions.
articles.abstract: The board of the F.D.I.C. moved to relax some proposed rules while still imposing tough standards on private equity firms seeking to buy troubled financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: New federal rules that might have encouraged private equity firms to snap up troubled banks could wind up keeping those buyers in their seats.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: Accused of Drug Ties, Afghan Official Worries U.S.
articles.snippet: The challenges posed by corruption in Afghanistan are revealed in President Hamid Karzai’s running mate.
articles.abstract: The challenges posed by corruption in Afghanistan are revealed in President Hamid Karzai’s running mate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It was a heated debate during the Bush administration: What to do about evidence that Afghanistan’s powerful defense minister was involved in drug trafficking? Officials from the time say they needed him to help run the troubled country. So the answer, in the end: look the other way.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Apple’s Sleek Upgrade
articles.snippet: A “smaller, faster and more refined” operating system for Mac.
articles.abstract: A “smaller, faster and more refined” operating system for Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buying software is not like buying a vase or a comb or a lawnmower where you pay, you take it home, and the transaction is complete.

articles.headline: More Sun for Less: Solar Panels Drop in Price
articles.snippet: More factories that make the material used in solar panels have opened, and the global demand for them has fallen.
articles.abstract: More factories that make the material used in solar panels have opened, and the global demand for them has fallen.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Greg Hare looked into putting solar panels on his ranch-style home in Magnolia, Tex., last year, he decided he could not afford it. “I had no idea solar was so expensive,” he recalled.

articles.headline: After Diagnosis, Determined to Make a ‘Good Ending’
articles.snippet: From the time his brain cancer was diagnosed 15 months ago, Senator Kennedy spoke of having a “good ending for myself.”
articles.abstract: From the time his brain cancer was diagnosed 15 months ago, Senator Kennedy spoke of having a “good ending for myself.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The once-indefatigable Ted Kennedy was in a wheelchair at the end, struggling to speak and sapped of his energy. But from the time his brain cancer was diagnosed 15 months ago, he spoke of having a “good ending for myself,” in whatever time he had left, and by every account, he did.

articles.headline: Toyota Tops List of Cash-for-Clunkers Winners
articles.snippet: The American cash-for-clunkers program turned out to be a boon for Asian automakers, taking in 45 percent of sales, versus 40 percent for Detroit automakers.
articles.abstract: The American cash-for-clunkers program turned out to be a boon for Asian automakers, taking in 45 percent of sales, versus 40 percent for Detroit automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The cash-for-clunkers program turned out to be a boon for Asian automakers and the small cars they specialize in.

articles.headline: An Overhaul or a Tweak for Pensions
articles.snippet: Some say the Governmental Accounting Standards Board should make public pension numbers more straightforward; others say its existing rules are sound.
articles.abstract: Some say the Governmental Accounting Standards Board should make public pension numbers more straightforward; others say its existing rules are sound.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than three years of deliberations, the board that sets the accounting rules for state and city governments is still far away from issuing a new standard for public pension funds.

articles.headline: Defying Experts, Rogue Computer Code Still Lurks
articles.snippet: A rogue program, known as Conficker, has confounded the efforts of security experts to trace its origins and purpose.
articles.abstract: A rogue program, known as Conficker, has confounded the efforts of security experts to trace its origins and purpose.

articles.headline: Boeing, Behind Schedule, Plans Dreamliner Flight
articles.snippet: Boeing said it would record a pretax charge of $2.5 billion in the third quarter because of the plane’s delays.
articles.abstract: Boeing said it would record a pretax charge of $2.5 billion in the third quarter because of the plane’s delays.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first test flight of Boeing’s long-delayed 787 Dreamliner passenger plane will happen by the end of 2009, some two years behind schedule, the company said on Thursday.

articles.headline: ‘Blood Oath’ Sealed Stanford Deal, Court Is Told
articles.snippet: The ceremony between R. Allen Stanford and Leroy King, the chief regulator of his Antigua bank, promoted a scheme to hide a multibillion-dollar fraud, according to court papers.
articles.abstract: The ceremony between R. Allen Stanford and Leroy King, the chief regulator of his Antigua bank, promoted a scheme to hide a multibillion-dollar fraud, according to court papers.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  R. Allen Stanford’s relationship with the chief regulator of his Antigua bank was closer than most.
